questions.text: A 55 year old worker at a construction site working during summer suddenly fainted and was brought to the Emergency room. Temperature was noted to be 105°F. He was diagnosed to be suffering from heat stroke. Which of the symptoms is least likely to be present in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sweating A core temperature ≥40°C accompanied by CNS dysfunction in patients with environmental heat exposure. This condition represents a failure of the body's ability to maintain thermoregulatory homeostasis. Clinical Manifestations CNS symptoms can be manifested as Impaired judgment inappropriate behavior Tachycardia, Resulting into Hypotension Tachypnea The skin may be flushed and warm or diaphoretic resulting in Red HOT SKIN Vomiting and diarrhea are also common.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Options A,B & D are Ruled Out.

Table:

#MANTRA Clinical features of heat stroke and heat exhaustion* Heat stroke Heat exhaustion Core body temperature >40°C (104°F)A ≤40°C (104°F) Mental status Abnormal mental status (eg, obtunded, coma, delirium, hallucinations, seizures, ataxia, slurred speech) Normal mental status, dizziness, or mild confusion that rapidly normalizes within 30 minutes of treatment. May see syncope with rapid recovery of alertness. Airway and breathing May be compromised due to altered mental status, tachypneic Clear airway, may be tachypneic Circulation Tachycardia with hypotension, moderate to severe dehydration Tachycardia with normal blood pressure, mild to moderate dehydration Skin findings Dry skin (classic heat stroke) or sweating (exertional heat stroke) Sweating Other clinical features ● Vomiting ● Diarrhea ● Clinical and laboratory findings of DIC, rhabdomyolysis, acute renal failure, cardiogenic shock, and liver failure ● Nausea, vomiting ● Headache ● Fatigue, weakness ● In some patients, hyponatremia or hypernatremia

questions.text: A 45 year old alcoholic male patient presented with pain in great toe on examination uric acid is normal in blood. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute Gouty arthritis Precipitation of monosodium urate crystals Pathology:- Neutrophils ingest crystals ⬇️ Inflammasome ⬇️ Release of enzymes ⬇️ FLARE For precipitation => lower temperature (away from the body i.e, distal cooler joints involved) CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS:- Monoarticular or oligoarticular (rare) (≤4joints) Most commonly => 1st metatarsophalangeal joint involved ( PODAGRA ) Ankle, interphalangeal, and Elbow joints (hip, shoulder, Knee joints not involved) At night =› severe attack of pain

Highyeild:

Synovial Fluid analysis Increased TLC Crystals => Na urate, negative birefringence Needle shaped (yellow appearance under parallel polarized light)

Extraedge:

The drugs used are: NSAIDs Colchicine Glucocorticoids because all of these are helpful in reducing inflammation in gout. DOC for Chronic Gout:- ALLOPURINOL

questions.text: An IT engineer patient present with complaints of Hematemesis and melena. He has a history of epigastric pain from a long period of time. He is taking alcohol occasionally. He is also taking aspirin. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peptic ulcer An IT engineer (Likely sedentary lifestyle) with long standing epigastric pain (Pancreatitis / GERD/ PUD) and being on Aspirin (Elderly age with coronary artery disease) with risk of NSAID induced ulceration, now presenting with upper GI bleed and melena. This likely scenario here appears to be of Peptic ulcer disease ( PUD ) Ulcers are defined as breaks in the mucosal surface > 5 mm in size, with depth to the submucosa A peptic ulcer is defined as disruption of the mucosal integrity of the stomach and/or duodenum leading to a local defect or excavation due to active inflammation GI bleeding is the most common complication observed in PUD (~15%). Bleeding and complications of ulcer disease occur more often in individuals >60 years of age due to the increased use of NSAIDs in this group. Causes of upper GI bleed PUD Gastroduodenitis Esophagitis Portal hypertensive Malignancy Tears across the gastroesophageal junction Vascular lesions Risk factors for PUD 1) H. pylori and NSAIDs - most common 2) Chronic obstructive lung disease 3) Chronic renal insufficiency 4) Current and former tobacco use 5) Older age 6) Coronary heart disease 7) Former alcohol use 8) African American race 9) Obesity 10) Diabetes 11) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) 12) Gastric bypass surgery 13) Idiopathic PUD

Highyeild:

The second most common ulcer-related complication is perforation (6-7%). Gastric outlet obstruction is the least common ulcer-related complication (1–2%).

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A - Esophagitis - inflammation of the esophageal mucosa that leads to microscopic injury and macroscopic erosions and ulcers likely secondary to refluxed gastric acid and pepsin. It can lead to hematemesis too but less often when compared to PUD Option C – Mallory Weiss tear – Non-transmural tear at the gastroesophageal junction usually due to vomiting, retching, or vigorous coughing leading to hematemesis. In this patient there is antecedent history of epigastric pain and no history of retching or vomiting and no binge bout of alcohol in history. Option D – Portal hypertension – Patients may present with hematemesis and melena along with other signs splenomegaly, ascites and edema. In this patient there are no evident signs mentioned.

Extraedge:

DUs (Duodenal ulcers) tend to penetrate posteriorly into the pancreas, leading to pancreatitis. GUs (Gastric ulcers) tend to penetrate into the left hepatic lobe

questions.text: Swelling in the anterior neck which moves with protrusion of tongue. What is The diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroglossal cyst A Thyroglossal duct cyst is a neck mass or lump that develops from cells and tissues remaining after the formation of the thyroid gland during embryonic development . They are typically located in the midline of the neck.

Highyeild:

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY During embryonic development the thyroid gland begins at the base of the tongue and moves down the neck through a canal called the thyroglossal duct. The duct normally disappears once the thyroid reaches its final position in the neck. Sometimes, portions of the duct remain, leaving cavities called cysts. These cysts fills with fluid or mucus Enlargement of the cyst due to infection Difficulty in swallowing or obstruction of breathing passages occurs.

Extraedge:

Treatment may include: Antibiotic medication for treating the infection Sistrunk procedure

questions.text: Usually patients with dialysis develop hyperkalemia, but sometimes they develop headaches, nausea and vomiting. This is called Dialysis Disequilibrium syndrome. What is management ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

i/v Mannitol The dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is characterized by a range of neurologic symptoms that affect patients on hemodialysis, particularly when they are first started on dialysis Risk factors for DDS include the following First hemodialysis treatment Markedly elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) concentration prior to a dialysis session (eg, >175 mg/dL or 60 mmol/L) Extremes of age Pre-existing neurologic diseases (head trauma, stroke, seizure disorder) Concomitant presence of other conditions that could be associated with cerebral edema (such as hyponatremia, hepatic encephalopathy, or hypertensive emergency) Concomitant presence of another condition associated with increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier (such as sepsis, vasculitis, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic uremic syndrome, encephalitis, or meningitis) Patients report headache, nausea, blurred vision, and restlessness that can progress to somnolence, confusion, disorientation , or mania. Among patients with persistent severe DDS (such as seizures, encephalopathy, or coma) despite the use of sodium modeling, a trial of hypertonic saline or mannitol is reasonable, where available. Either 5 mL of 23 percent saline or 12.5 g of mannitol is used to rapidly raise the serum osmolality and to prevent further osmotic shifts.

questions.text: 70 years old man with slowing of movements and staring at sky. On autopsy Lewy bodies are seen. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PRION As the patient has fluctuating cognition and bizarre, visual hallucinations, Parkinsonism features (rigidity+tremor), increased sensitivity to antipsychotics,

Highyeild:

Lewy body dementia- Early visual hallucination REM sleep abnormality Delirium/fluctuating-mental status Capgras syndrome-false belief that an identical duplicate has replaced someone significant to the patient. Increased sensitivity to medicines like Antipsychotics→ Increase risk of Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Syncopal episodes Autonomic dysfunction Memory is not affected Parkinsonism→ Dementia Gap>2yr: Parkinson's associated dementia Gap<1yr: Lewy body dementia

Extraedge:

Alzheimer's disease Lewy body dementia Vascular dementia Language Affected Not severe Sometimes severe Memory Impaired storage Impaired retrieval Impaired retrieval Clues Not helpful Bizarre visual hallucination, Parkinsonism Step ladder decline, Ischemic disease history Visuospatial impairment + +++ + Executive functions Mildly affected-early Prominent impaired Variable Mental speed Normal Slow Slow

Table:

#MANTRA SYMPTOMS/SIGNS ALTERNATIVE DIAGNOSIS TO CONSIDER History Early speech and gait impairment (Lack of tremor, lack of motor asymmetry) Atypical parkinsonism Exposure to neuroleptics Drug-induced parkinsonism Onset prior to age 40 Genetic form of PD Liver disease Wilson's disease, non-Wilsonian hepatolenticular degeneration Early hallucinations and dementia with later development of PD features Dementia with Lewy bodies Diplopia, impaired down gaze PSP Poor or no response to an adequate trial of levodopa Atypical or secondary parkinsonism Physical Examination Dementia as first or early feature Prominent orthostatic hypotension Dementia with Lewy bodies Prominent orthostatic hypotension MSA-P Prominent cerebellar signs MSA-c Slow saccades with impaired down gaze PSP High-frequency (6-10 Hz) symmetric postural tremor with a prominent kinetic component Essential tremor

questions.text: After Prolonged treatment of Asthma, patients on inhalers developed oral white patches. What will be the DOC?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flucytosine Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungus (yeast) It can infect the mouth, vagina, skin, stomach, and urinary tract. Thrush is the presence of creamy white, slightly raised lesions in your mouth -usually on the tongue . The lesions can be painful and may bleed slightly when scrape them In severe cases, the lesions may spread into your esophagus , or swallowing tube, causing pain or difficulty swallowing.

Highyeild:

Local predisposing factors for candidiasis General predisposing factors ● Denture wearing ● Smoking ● Atopic constitution ● Inhalation steroids ● Topical steroids ● Hyperkeratosis ● Imbalance of oral microflora ● Quality and quantity of saliva ● Immunosuppressive diseases ● Immunosuppressive drugs ● Chemotherapy ● Endocrine disorders ● Hematinic deficiencies

Table:

#MANTRA DRUG FORM DOSAGE Amphotericin B Lozenge, 10 mg Slowly dissolved in the mouth, 3-4 times/day after meals, for 2 weeks Nystatin Cream Apply to affected areas 3-4 times/day Clotrimazole Cream Apply to the affected areas, 2- 3 times/day, for 3 days Ketoconazole Tablets 200-400mg tablets, taken once or twice daily with food, for 2 weeks. Fluconazole Capsules 50-100 mg capsules, once daily, for 2-3 weeks.

questions.text: A drug that inhibits both ACE and Neprilysin inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Omapatrilat

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: In individuals with HIV, the increased incidence and persistence of which viral skin infection is commonly observed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Molluscum Contagiosum Virus Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by Molluscum Contagiosum Virus. In individuals with HIV, the weakened immune system can lead to an increased incidence and persistence of molluscum contagiosum lesions. Other viral skin infections, such as herpes simplex, human papillomavirus, and varicella-zoster virus, may also be observed in individuals with HIV but are not as specifically associated with increased persistence as molluscum contagiosum.

Highyeild:

Histologically , it is characterized by molluscum bodies in the epidermis above the stratum basale , which consist of large cells with : abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (accumulated virions), and a small peripheral nucleus. Cryosurgery : The dermatologist freezes the bumps with liquid nitrogen.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A:- Histoplasmosis show Fibrocaseous Nodule Option B :- It Shows Negative Ink Staining Positive Option D: - It Will Show Bilateral Infiltrates in Lungs

questions.text: What is the next-line of investigation in this position?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroid receptor Ab This Points Towards The Diagnosis Of Graves Disease. Autoimmune disorder resulting increased synthesis & release of thyroid hormones Graves Ophthalmology Signs:- Von Graefe's sign- lid lag on downgaze Dalrymple's sign- lid retraction Stellwag's sign- incomplete & infrequent blinking Grove sign- resistance to pulling the retracted upper lid Boston sign- jerky movements of the lid on downgaze Gellineck's sign- abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid Gifford's sign - difficulty in everting the upper lid

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: - Anti TPo Antibody Results In Hashimoto Thyroiditis Option B: - Ultrasensitive Thyrotropin levels give an indication of Hypo/HyperThyroidism. Option C: - Thyroglobulin antibody also indicates Hashimoto Thyroiditis

Extraedge:

RX OF GRAVE'S DISEASE B - Blocker Antithyroid drugs: Methimazole Carbimazole Propylthiouracil Surgery / iodine ablation

questions.text: Sweat chloride levels are measured for which disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystic fibrosis The Sweat Chloride Test Is Done For cystic Fibrosis Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects epithelial cells of the respiratory, gastrointestinal and reproductive tracts and leads to abnormal exocrine gland secretions. An individual must inherit a defective copy of the CF gene (one from each parent) to have CF. Pathophysiology CF is due to a mutation in the CF gene or chromosome 7. The CF gene encodes a protein known as the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR). The abnormal CFTR protein in patients with CF leads to disruption of chloride channels on the cells.

Highyeild:

CT is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis. The signet ring sign is seen when dilated bronchus is seen. Thickened secretions are seen in a tree-in-bud pattern. Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus String of beads appearance and cluster of grapes appearance is also present.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B - Antitrypsin Deficiency Can Even Lead To Bronchiectasis Option: C - Celiac Disease can be diagnosed by Transglutaminase antibodies Option: D - Whipple Disease is a bacterial infection affecting GIT.

Extraedge:

Initial radiographic findings of CF include Air trapping and linear markings, and Subsequent findings include nodular-cystic lesions representing bronchiectasis and mucus plugging On CT, CF manifests

questions.text: A patient was transfused 4 units of blood in 6 hours. After which , the patient developed breathlessness and crepitus. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute lung injury Acute onset. Hypoxemia: PaO,/FiO, <300 mmHg; OR Oxygen saturation is <90% on room air ; OR Other clinical evidence Bilateral lung infiltrates on the chest radiograph. No evidence of circulatory overload.

Highyeild:

Signs & Symptoms Respiratory distress Tachypnea Hypoxemia Hypotension Noncardiogenic pulmonary edema Fever:- Onset within 6 hours of transfusion Supporting Data B/L pulmonary infiltrates on CXR Decreased WBC count Associated with HLA and/or Neutrophil Antibodies

Extraedge:

RISK FACTORS FOR ACUTE LUNG INJURY Direct Lung Injury Aspiration Pneumonia Toxic inhalation Lung contusion Near drowning Indirect Lung Injury Severe sepsis Shock Multiple trauma Burn injury Acute pancreatitis Cardiopulmonary bypass Drug overdose

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A female patient presents with hypertension, tremors, neck swelling and a known case of asthma. ECG findings show signs of A. Fib. What would be the next immediate step to relieve the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diltiazem Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia Spontaneous discharge by ectopic pacemaker cells in large pulmonary veins @ point where they join LA

Highyeild:

ECG FEATURES OF AF Irregularly irregular rhythm No P Waves Absence of an isoelectric baseline. Variable ventricular rate QRS complexes usually <120 ms unless pre-existing bundle branch block, accessory pathway, or Rate related aberrant conduction. Fibrillatory waves may be present and can be either fine (amplitude <0.5 mm or coarse amplitude >0.5 mm)

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology:- Electrophysiological changes occur in the atria within a few hours of the onset of AF that tend to maintain fibrillation: electrical remodelling When AF persists for a period of months, structural remodelling occurs with atrial fibrosis and dilatation that further predispose to AF Thus early treatment of AF will prevent this and reinitiating of the arrhythmia

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A poor female eating only rice and pulses presents with pallor with cheilitis and inflammation; sensory, touch and proprioception lost, ankle reflex absent, UMN weakness is also seen. What is the most probable diagnosis for the given case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SACD Accumulated methylmalonic acid believed to cause myelin toxicity Possible pregulation of tumor necrosis factor and downregulation of epidermal growth factor Causes of B12 deficiency Gl malabsorption - pernicious anemia (lack of intrinsic factor), post-gastrectomy, Crohn disease, and celiac disease Nutritional deficiency

Highyeild:

Pathology:- Loss of myelin in the spinal cord white matter tracts: Dorsal columns Typical pattern of involvement Lateral columns Ventral columns Imaging Findings MRI shows, high T2 signal intensity , involving the cervical and/or the thoracic spinal cord in: Dorsal, lateral and ventral white matter Cord diameter is normal No Gd enhancement

Extraedge:

Signs & Symptoms Legs, arms, trunk - progressive from tingling and numbness to weakness Visual impairment Change in mental state BILATERAL spastic paresis/paralysis Sensations diminished = pressure, vibration and touch

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A patient is taking anti gout medications, which drug works by inhibiting the synthesis of uric acid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Allopurinol Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism , characterized by:- intermittent attacks of acute pain, swelling and inflammation It always preceded by hyperuricemia (6.0mg/dl) Hyperuricemia due to excessive amount of uric acid production or decreased excretion. Acute gout Painful arthritic attack of sudden onset. Usually occurring at night or in early morning Arthritic pain worse progressively Generally involves one or few joints Most common site of initial attack metatarsophalangeal joint. Other sites include ankle, heel, knee, wrist, elbow and fingers.

Highyeild:

The properties of synovial fluid in gout Patients are: Brightly birefringent crystal with negative elongation, leukocyte count from 2000 to 60000/mm3 large amounts of crystal, resulting in thick and pasty or chalky fluid.

Extraedge:

The drugs used are: NSAIDS Colchicine Glucocorticoids because all of this help reduce inflammation in gout. DOC for Chronic Gout:- ALLOPURINOL

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Pt is having mid diastolic murmur and atrial fibrillation was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral stenosis Commonest cause : Rheumatic heart disease Infections with group A beta hemolytic streptococci More common in women Inflammation leads to commissural fusion and a reduction in mitral valve orifice area

Extraedge:

1 . Left arterial pressure increases Left arterial hypertrophy and dilation Pulmonary veins, pulmonary arterial and R/ heart pressure increases Increase of pulmonary capillary pressure Followed by development of:- pulmonary oedema Atrial fibrillation with tachycardia Loss of coordinated atrial contraction This is prevented by (Reactive pulmonary hypertension):- Alveolar and capillary thickening Pulmonary arterial vasoconstriction Pulmonary hypertension leads to:- R/ ventricular hypertrophy , dilation and failure with subsequent tricuspid regurgitation

Table:

#MANTRA First heart sound (S1) is accentuated & snapping Opening snap (OS) after aortic valve closure Low pitch diastolic rumble at the apex Pre-systolic accentuation (esp. if in sinus rhythm)

questions.text: A pt was on chemotherapy for cancer and he developed thrombocytopenia. what is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oprelvekin Subnormal amount of platelets in peripheral blood Normal range: 5 lakhs to 4.5 lakhs per u Abnormal : <50,000 per u Count between 20,000 to 50,000 per u Bleeding with trauma or surgery or mild spontaneous bleeding Count <20,000 per Spontaneous and severe hemorrhage

Highyeild:

Bone Marrow examination Megakaryocytes Number- normal or increase Morphology - Hypogranular cytoplasm Vacuolation Lack of platelets budding Nuclear hypolobation Dense nuclear chromatin Coagulation profile Bleeding time- increased Clot retraction- deficient Platelets antibodies Increased platelet-associated immunoglobulin

Extraedge:

Causes Of Thrombocytopenia:- Increase destruction of platelets Immune Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura Systemic lupus erythematosus Drugs : Heparin, gold salts, penicillin, quinidine, quinine Infections: HIV, malaria, dengue, HCV, Helicobacter pylori Post transfusion purpura Neonatal alloimmune purpura Non-immune Disseminated intravascular coagulation Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura/ Haemolytic Uremic syndrome Giant haemangioma Decrease production of platelets Hereditary Fanconi's anaemia Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome Acquired Aplastic anaemia Bone marrow infiltration (leukemia, myelodysplasia, myelofibrosis Megaloblastic anaemia Drugs (cytotoxic drugs, ethanol), radiation Viral infections

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Loss of vision in the right half of both eyes lesions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left optic tract

Highyeild:

CAUSES:- Tumors located at the mid-optic chiasm. Pituitary Gland tumors: They press upwards from the sella turcica (bony border) on the bottom of the optic chiasm. Tumors include:- Adenomas Craniopharyngiomas Aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery which passes superior to the chiasm.

Extraedge:

VISUAL PATHWAYS A normal visual pathway has the following components: Retina Optic nerves Optic chiasm: where optic nerve fires from the nasal hemiretina of both sides decussate and pass to the opposite optic tract. Optic tracts LGN Optic Radiation or geniculocalcarine tract Primary Visual Cortex or Brodmann's Area 17

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: 20yrs with 6 pack years .,he has cough ,chest pain,his tests revealed hypercalcemia .what's the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Squamous cell carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Moderate to poor differentiation makes up 30-40% of all lung cancers more common in males most occur centrally in the large bronchi Uncommon metastasis that is slow affects the liver, adrenal glands and lymph nodes. Associated with smoking Most likely presents as a Pancoast's tumor

Highyeild:

DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP History : metastasis symptoms PE : H & N lymph nodes Chest X-ray CT : the most valuable radiologic study for evaluation, staging, and therapeutic planning of lung cancer MRI : mediastinum or paravertebral region Bone scans : stage III before curative therapy Brain CT scan: small cell carcinoma Pulmonary function tests: ability to undergo surgical resection or withstand irradiation Needle biopsy:- can often use a hollow needle to get a small sample from a suspicious area (mass). Bronchoscopy:- can help find some tumors or blockages in the lungs. Thoracoscopy :- spread to the spaces between the lungs and the chest wall, or to the linings

Extraedge:

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY :- DUE TO ETIOLOGICAL FACTORS ⬇️ DAMAGE TO THE CELL ⬇️ CARCINIGEN BIND TO DAMAGED CELL DNA ⬇️ CELLULAR CHANGES ⬇️ PASSED TO THE DAUGHTER CELL ⬇️ EVENTUALLY MALIGNANT CELL ⬇️ MALIGNANT TRANSFORM FROM NORMAL EPITHELIUM ⬇️ CARCINOMA

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Worker in the cement factory presents with asbestosis breathing difficulty and weight loss.,diagnosed as mesothelioma, what's the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Asbestosis Asbestosis Asbestos consists of certain types of fibrous material made up of silicates Silica may be combined with: Magnesium Iron Calcium Aluminum Asbestos is of two types: Serpentine or Chrysolite Hydrated magnesium 90% of world’s asbestos production Amphibole Contains little magnesium Fibers are straight and longer than chrysotile fibers

Highyeild:

Chest X-ray:- irregular opacities in the lower lobes, The heart border becomes shaggy. In the late stages of disease, there is a honey-comb likeness and volume loss.

Extraedge:

Causes : by breathing in small particles of asbestos. They get stuck in the lungs causing scarring and inflammation to occur. Symptoms : swelling in the neck or face difficulty swallowing high blood pressure blood in sputum crackling sound when breathing shortness of breath hypertension finger deformity loss of weight/appetite coughing

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Clinical scenario of carpal tunnel syndrome . Patient presented with a tingling sensation in lateral 3 1/2 fingers. It is due to the compression of the nerve. Diagnosis and test asked.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carpal tunnel syndrome-Durkan's test Carpal tunnel syndrome is pressure on the median nerve -- the nerve in the wrist that supplies feeling and movement to parts of the hand. It can lead to:- numbness, tingling, weakness, or muscle damage in the hand and fingers.

Highyeild:

Tinel sign: is a way to detect irritated nerves . It is performed by lightly tapping (percussing) over the nerve to elicit a sensation of tingling or "pins and needles" in the distribution of the nerve Phalen's maneuver is a diagnostic test for carpal tunnel syndrome Nerve Conduction Studies:- Prolongation of the distal latencies of the median motor and sensory evoked potentials

Extraedge:

Causes:- Usually the cause is unknown Pressure on the nerve can happen several ways: swelling of the lining of the flexor tendons, called tenosynovitis . Joint dislocations Fractures Osteoarthritis can narrow the tunnel Posture - keeping the wrist bent for long periods of time Repetitive wrist movements Fluid retention during pregnancy can cause swelling in the tunnel and symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome, which often go away after delivery. Thyroid conditions (hypothyroidism) Rheumatoid arthritis Diabetes mellitus

Table:

#MANTRA
